ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Transport] This protocol [MS-OXCRPC] works over the following RPC protocol sequences:<1> [ncacn_ip_tcp, ncacn_http].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1889, MS-OXCRPC_R1936.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Transport] For the network protocol sequence ncacn_http, this protocol MUST use the well-known endpoint 6001.
[In Transport] For ncacn_ip_tcp, this protocol MUST use RPC dynamic endpoints, as defined in Part 4 of [C706].
[In Transport] This protocol MUST use the UUID specified in section 1.9.
[In Transport] This protocol allows any user to establish an authenticated connection to the RPC server by using an authentication method as specified in [MS-RPCE].
[In Transport] The protocol [MS-OXCRPC] uses the underlying RPC protocol to retrieve the identity of the caller that made the method call, as specified in [MS-RPCE].
[In Transport] The server uses this identity [retrieved by the protocol using the underlying RPC protocol] to perform method-specific access checks.

[In Common Data Types] This protocol uses the RPC base types and definitions specified in [C706] and [MS-RPCE], plus additional data types and structures that are defined in section [CXH, ACXH, BIG_RANGE_ULONG, SMALL_RANGE_ULONG, RPC_HEADER_EXT, AUX_HEADER, AUX_PERF_REQUESTID, AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO, AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO_V2, AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO, AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO, AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO, AUX_PERF_DEFMDB_SUCCESS, AUX_PERF_DEFGC_SUCCESS, AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS, AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2, AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS, AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS_V2, AUX_PERF_FAILURE, AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2, AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL, AUX_OSVERSIONINFO, AUX_EXORGINFO, AUX_PERF_ACCOUNTINFO, AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES, AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES, AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO, AUX_SERVER_SESSION_INFO and AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION] 2.2.1.1 through section 2.2.2.2.22.

[In Common Data Types] The following table lists the types and structures [CXH, ACXH, BIG_RANGE_ULONG, SMALL_RANGE_ULONG, RPC_HEADER_EXT,AUX_HEADER, AUX_PERF_REQUESTID, AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO, AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO_V2, AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO, AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO, AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO, AUX_PERF_DEFMDB_SUCCESS, AUX_PERF_DEFGC_SUCCESS, AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS, AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2, AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS, AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS_V2, AUX_PERF_FAILURE, AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2, AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL, AUX_OSVERSIONINFO, AUX_EXORGINFO, AUX_PERF_ACCOUNTINFO,AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES ,AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES, AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO, AUX_SERVER_SESSION_INFO and AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION] that are defined in this specification [MS-OXCRPC].
[In Common Data Types] Any structure that is not defined in this specification [MS-OXCRPC] is reserved.
[In Common Data Types] Any structure that is not defined in this specification [MS-OXCRPC] MUST be ignored by the client.

[In Simple Data Types] The Interface Definition Language (IDL) for this protocol, as given in section 6, identifies four Simple Data Types [CXH, ACXH, BIG_RANGE_ULONG and SMALL_RANGE_ULONG], which are defined in section 2.2.1.1 through section 2.2.1.4.
[In CXH Data Type] The CXH data type is a session context handle to be used with an EMSMDB interface, as specified in section 3.1 and section 3.2.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R406, MS-OXCRPC_R427, MS-OXCRPC_R483, MS-OXCRPC_R625.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In ACXH Data Type] The AXCH data type is an asynchronous context handle to be used with an AsyncEMSMDB interface, as specified in section 3.3 and section 3.4.
[In BIG_RANGE_ULONG Data Type] The BIG_RANGE_ULONG data type is an unsigned long that MUST be between 0x0 and 0x40000.
[In SMALL_RANGE_ULONG Data Type] The SMALL_RANGE_ULONG data type is an unsigned long that MUST be between 0x0 and 0x1008.
[In Structures] Unless otherwise specified, buffers and fields in section 2.2.2.1 through section 2.2.2.2.22 are depicted in little-endian byte order.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] The RPC_HEADER_EXT structure provides information about the payload that follows.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] Version (2 bytes): The version of the structure.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R33.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Version (2 bytes)] This value MUST be set to 0x0000.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] Flags (2 bytes): The flags that specify how data that follows this header [RPC_HEADER_EXT] MUST be interpreted.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Flags (2 bytes)] The flags [Compressed, XorMagic, Last] in the following table are valid.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Flags (2 bytes)] [Compressed 0x0001] The data that follows the RPC_HEADER_EXT structure is compressed.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Flags (2 bytes)] [Compressed 0x0001] The size of the data when uncompressed is in the SizeActual field.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Flags (2 bytes)] [Compressed 0x0001] If this flag is not set, the Size and SizeActual fields MUST be the same.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Flags (2 bytes)] [Compressed 0x0001] If this flag is set, the value of the Size field MUST be less than the value of the SizeActual field.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Flags (2 bytes)] [XorMagic 0x0002] The data following the RPC_HEADER_EXT structure has been obfuscated.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Flags (2 bytes)] [XorMagic 0x0002] For more details about the obfuscation algorithm, see section 3.1.4.1.1.3.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Flags (2 bytes)] [Last 0x0004] No other RPC_HEADER_EXT structure follows the data of the current RPC_HEADER_EXT structure.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Flags (2 bytes)] [Last 0x0004] This flag indicates that there are multiple buffers, each with its own RPC_HEADER_EXT, one after the other.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R775, MS-OXCRPC_R778, MS-OXCRPC_R779.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] Size (2 bytes): The total length of the payload data that follows the RPC_HEADER_EXT structure.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R46.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [Size (2 bytes)] This length does not include the length of the RPC_HEADER_EXT structure.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R46.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] SizeActual (2 bytes): The length of the payload data after it has been uncompressed.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R46.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [SizeActual (2 bytes)] This field is only useful if the Compressed flag is set in the Flags field.
[In RPC_HEADER_EXT Structure] [SizeActual (2 bytes)] If the Compressed flag is not set, this value [SizeActual] MUST be equal to the value of the Size field.
[In AUX_HEADER Structure] The AUX_HEADER structure provides information about the auxiliary block structures that follow it.
[In AUX_HEADER Structure] Size (2 bytes): The size of the AUX_HEADER structure plus any additional payload data that follows.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R993.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_HEADER Structure] Version (1 byte): The version information of the payload data that follows the AUX_HEADER structure.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1061, MS-OXCRPC_R1073, MS-OXCRPC_R990.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_HEADER Structure] [Version (1 byte)] This value in conjunction with the Type field determines which structure to use to interpret the data that follows the header.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R55.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_HEADER Structure] [Version (1 byte)] The value of version "AUX_VERSION_1" is "0x01".
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1061, MS-OXCRPC_R1073, MS-OXCRPC_R990.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_HEADER Structure] [Version (1 byte)] The value of version "AUX_VERSION_2" is "0x02".
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1061, MS-OXCRPC_R1073, MS-OXCRPC_R990.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_HEADER Structure] Type (1 byte): The type of auxiliary block data structure that follows the AUX_HEADER structure.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1061, MS-OXCRPC_R1073, MS-OXCRPC_R990.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_HEADER Structure] [Type (1 byte)] The value of the Type field in conjunction with the Version field determines which auxiliary block structure to use to interpret the data that follows the AUX_HEADER structure.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1061, MS-OXCRPC_R1073, MS-OXCRPC_R990.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_HEADER Structure] [Type (1 byte)] Several of the types distinguish among the client's foreground request (FG), the client's background request (BG), and the client's global catalog request (GC).
[In AUX_HEADER Structure] A foreground request is a request where the client is waiting for a response from the server before continuing
[In AUX_HEADER Structure] A background request is a request where the client is operating in cached mode versus online.
[In AUX_HEADER Structure] A global catalog request is a client request sent to the mailbox directory.

[In AUX_HEADER Structure] [Type (1 byte)] The block type names, associated Type field values, and the corresponding auxiliary block structure that follows the AUX_HEADER structure when the Version field is AUX_VERSION_1 are listed in the following table [The types are: AUX_TYPE_PERF_REQUESTID 0x01, AUX_TYPE_PERF_CLIENTDINFO 0x02, AUX_TYPE_PERF_SERVERINFO 0x03, AUX_TYPE_PERF_SESSIONINFO 0x04, AUX_TYPE_PERF_DEFMDB_SUCCESS 0x05, AUX_TYPE_PERF_DEFGC_SUCCESS 0x06, AUX_TYPE_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS 0x07, AUX_TYPE_PERF_GC_SUCCESS 0x08, AUX_TYPE_PERF_FAILURE 0x09, AUX_TYPE_CLIENT_CONTROL 0x0A, AUX_TYPE_PERF_PROCESSINFO 0x0B, AUX_TYPE_PERF_BG_DEFMDB_SUCCESS 0x0C, AUX_TYPE_PERF_BG_DEFGC_SUCCESS 0x0D, AUX_TYPE_PERF_BG_MDB_SUCCESS 0x0E, AUX_TYPE_PERF_BG_GC_SUCCESS 0x0F, AUX_TYPE_PERF_BG_FAILURE 0x10, AUX_TYPE_PERF_FG_DEFMDB_SUCCESS 0x11, AUX_TYPE_PERF_FG_DEFGC_SUCCESS 0x12, AUX_TYPE_PERF_FG_MDB_SUCCESS 0x13, AUX_TYPE_PERF_FG_GC_SUCCESS 0x14, AUX_TYPE_PERF_FG_FAILURE 0x15, AUX_TYPE_OSVERSIONINFO 0x16, AUX_TYPE_EXORGINO 0x17, AUX_TYPE_PERF_ACCOUNTINFO 0x18, AUX_TYPE_SERVER_CAPABILITIES 0x46, AUX_TYPE_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES 0x48, AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO 0x4A, AUX_SERVER_SESSION_INFO 0X4B, AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION 0X4E].

[In AUX_HEADER Structure] [Type (1 byte)] When the Version field is AUX_VERSION_1 and the type value is "AUX_TYPE_PERF_REQUESTID 0x01", means "AUX_PERF_REQUESTID" structure will follow the AUX_HEADER.

[In AUX_HEADER Structure] [Type (1 byte)] When the Version field is AUX_VERSION_1 and the type value is "AUX_TYPE_PERF_CLIENTDINFO 0x02", means "AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO" structure will follow the AUX_HEADER.

[In AUX_HEADER Structure] The auxiliary block structures are specified in section 2.2.2.2.1 through section 2.2.2.2.22.
[In AUX_PERF_REQUESTID Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_REQUESTID auxiliary block structure identifies the request associated with the session.
[In AUX_PERF_REQUESTID Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_REQUESTID Auxiliary Block Structure] RequestID (2 bytes): The RPC request identification.
[In AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO auxiliary block structure identifies the client session to associate performance data with.
[In AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionGuid (16 bytes): The GUID representing the client session to associate with the session identification number in the SessionID field.
[In AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO_V2] The AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO_V2 auxiliary block structure provides diagnostic information about the client session to the server.
[In AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionGuid (16 bytes): The GUID representing the client session to associate with the session identification number in the SessionID field.
[In AUX_PERF_SESSIONINFO_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ConnectionID (4 bytes): The connection identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO auxiliary block structure identifies which client to associate performance data with.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] AdapterSpeed (4 bytes): The speed of client computer's network adapter, in kilobits per second.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientID (2 bytes): The client-assigned client identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] MachineNameOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the MachineName field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [MachineNameOffset (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the MachineName field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] UserNameOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the UserName field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [UserNameOffset (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the UserName field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientIPSize (2 bytes): The size of the client IP address referenced by the ClientIPOffset field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientIPSize (2 bytes)] The client IP address is located in the ClientIP field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientIPOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the ClientIP field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientIPOffset (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the ClientIP field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientIPMaskSize (2 bytes): The size of the client IP subnet mask referenced by the ClientIPMaskOffset field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientIPMaskSize (2 bytes)] The client IP mask is located in the ClientIPMask field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientIPMaskOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the ClientIPMask field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientIPMaskOffset (2 bytes)] The size of the IP subnet mask is found in the ClientIPMaskSize field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientIPMaskOffset (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the ClientIPMask field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] AdapterNameOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the AdapterName field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [AdapterNameOffset (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the AdapterName field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] MacAddressSize (2 bytes): The size of the network adapter Media Access Control (MAC)address referenced by the MacAddressOffset field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [MacAddressSize (2 bytes)] The network adapter MAC address is located in the MacAddress field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] MacAddressOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the MacAddress field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [MacAddressOffset (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the MacAddress field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientMode (2 bytes): A flag that shows the mode in which the client is running.

[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientMode (2 bytes)] The valid values are specified in the following table.[CLIENTMODE_UNKNOWN 0x00, CLIENTMODE_CLASSIC 0x01, CLIENTMODE_CACHED 0x02].
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientMode (2 bytes)] Mode CLIENTMODE_UNKNOWN 0x00 means client is not designating a mode of operation.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientMode (2 bytes)] Mode CLIENTMODE_CLASSIC 0x01 means client is running in classic online mode.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientMode (2 bytes)] Mode CLIENTMODE_CACHED 0x02 means client is running in cached mode.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] MachineName (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the client computer name.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [MachineName (variable)] This variable field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the MachineNameOffset field value.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] UserName (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the user's account name.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [UserName (variable)] This variable field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the UserNameOffset field value.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientIP (variable): The client's IP address.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientIP (variable)] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the ClientIPOffset field value.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientIP (variable)] The size of the client IP address data is found in the ClientIPSize field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientIPMask (variable): The client's IP subnet mask.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientIPMask (variable)] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the ClientIPMaskOffset field value.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientIPMask (variable)] The size of the client IP mask data is found in the ClientIPMaskSize field.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] AdapterName (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the client network adapter name.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [AdapterName (variable)] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the AdapterNameOffset field value.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] MacAddress (variable): The client's network adapter MAC address.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [MacAddress (variable)] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the MacAddressOffset field value.
[In AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [MacAddress (variable)] The size of the network adapter MAC address data is found in the MacAddressSize field.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO auxiliary block structure identifies which server a client is communicating with to associate the performance data.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerID (2 bytes): The client assigned server identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerType (2 bytes): The server type assigned by client.

[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerType (2 bytes)] The following table specifies valid values [SERVERTYPE_UNKNOWN 0x00, SERVERTYPE_PRIVATE 0x01, SERVERTYPE_PUBLIC 0x02, SERVERTYPE_DIRECTORY 0x03, SERVERTYPE_REFERRAL 0x04].
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerType (2 bytes)] Type SERVERTYPE_UNKNOWN 0x00 means unknown server type.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerType (2 bytes)] Type SERVERTYPE_PRIVATE 0x01 means client/server connection servicing private mailbox data.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerType (2 bytes)] Type SERVERTYPE_PUBLIC 0x02 means client/server connection servicing public folder data.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerType (2 bytes)] Type SERVERTYPE_DIRECTORY 0x03 means client/server connection servicing directory data.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerType (2 bytes)] Type SERVERTYPE_REFERRAL 0x04 means client/server connection servicing referrals.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerDNOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the ServerDN field.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerDNOffset (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the ServerDN field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerNameOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the ServerName field.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerNameOffset (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the ServerName field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerDN (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the DN of the server.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerDN (variable)] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the ServerDNOffset field value.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerName (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the server name.
[In AUX_PERF_SERVERINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerName (variable)] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the ServerNameOffset field value.
[In AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO auxiliary block structure identifies the client process to associate performance data with.
[In AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ProcessID (2 bytes): The client-assigned process identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved_1 (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ProcessGuid (16 bytes): The GUID representing the client process to associate with the process identification number in the ProcessID field.
[In AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ProcessNameOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the ProcessName field.
[In AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ProcessNameOffset (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the ProcessName field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved_2 (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ProcessName (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the client process name.
[In AUX_PERF_PROCESSINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ProcessName (variable)] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the ProcessNameOffset field value.
[In AUX_PERF_DEFMDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_DEFMDB_SUCCESS auxiliary block structure reports a previously successful RPC to the messaging server.
[In AUX_PERF_DEFMDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeSinceRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds since a successful request occurred.
[In AUX_PERF_DEFMDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeToCompleteRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds the successful request took to complete.
[In AUX_PERF_DEFMDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] RequestID (2 bytes): The request identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_DEFMDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.

[In AUX_PERF_DEFGC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerID (2 bytes): The server identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_DEFGC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.

[In AUX_PERF_DEFGC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeToCompleteRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds the successful request took to complete.
[In AUX_PERF_DEFGC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] RequestOperation (1 byte): The client-defined operation that was successful.
[In AUX_PERF_DEFGC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved (3 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS auxiliary block structure reports a previously successful RPC to the messaging server.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientID (2 bytes): The client identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerID (2 bytes): The server identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] RequestID (2 bytes): The request identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeSinceRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds since successful request occurred.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeToCompleteRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds the successful request took to complete.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2 auxiliary header structure reports a previously successful RPC to the server.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ProcessID (2 bytes): The process identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientID (2 bytes): The client identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerID (2 bytes): The server identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.

[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeSinceRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds since successful request occurred.
[In AUX_PERF_MDB_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeToCompleteRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds the successful request took to complete.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS auxiliary block structure reports a previously successful call to the directory service.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientID (2 bytes): The client identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerID (2 bytes): The server identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved_1 (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeSinceRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds since successful request occurred.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeToCompleteRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds the successful request took to complete.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] RequestOperation (1 byte): The client-defined operation that was successful.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved_2 (3 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.

[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ProcessID (2 bytes): The process identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientID (2 bytes): The client identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerID (2 bytes): The server identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeSinceRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds since successful request occurred.
[In AUX_PERF_GC_SUCCESS_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeToCompleteRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds the successful request took to complete.

[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_FAILURE auxiliary block structure reports a previously failed call to the messaging server or the directory service.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientID (2 bytes): The client identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerID (2 bytes): The server identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] RequestID (2 bytes): The request identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeSinceRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds since a request failure occurred.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeToFailRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds the failed request took to complete.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] ResultCode (4 bytes): The error code returned for the failed request.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] ResultCode (4 bytes): Returned error codes are implementation-specific.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] RequestOperation (1 byte): The client-defined operation that failed.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved (3 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 auxiliary block structure reports a previously failed call to the messaging server or the directory service.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ProcessID (2 bytes): The process identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientID (2 bytes): The client identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerID (2 bytes): The server identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] SessionID (2 bytes): The session identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] RequestID (2 bytes): The request identification number.

[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] TimeToFailRequest (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds the request failure took to complete.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ResultCode (4 bytes): The error code return for the failed request.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] ResultCode (4 bytes): Returned error codes are implementation-specific.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] RequestOperation (1 byte): The client-defined operation that failed.
[In AUX_PERF_FAILURE_V2 Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved_2 (3 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL auxiliary block structure reports a change in client behavior.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] EnableFlags [in block AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL is] 4 bytes.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] [EnableFlags (4 bytes)] The flags that instruct the client to either enable or disable behavior.

[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] EnableFlags (4 bytes): The flag values [ENABLE_PERF_SENDTOSERVER 0x00000001, ENABLE_PERF_SENDTOMAILBOX 0x00000002, ENABLE_COMPRESSION 0x00000004, ENABLE_HTTP_TUNNELING 0x00000008, ENABLE_PERF_SENDGCDATA 0x00000010] and their meanings are described in the following table.

[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] [EnableFlags (4 bytes)] To disable a client behavior, the server does not set the flag to the specified value [0x00000001, 0x00000004, 0x00000008, 0x000000010].
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] [EnableFlags (4 bytes)] Flag ENABLE_PERF_SENDTOSERVER 0x00000001 means client MUST start sending performance information to server.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] [EnableFlags (4 bytes)] Flag ENABLE_COMPRESSION 0x00000004 means client MUST compress information up to the server.

[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] [EnableFlags (4 bytes)] [Flag "ENABLE_COMPRESSION 0x00000004] Compression MUST ordinarily be the default behavior, but this allows the server to "disable" compression.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] [EnableFlags (4 bytes)] Flag ENABLE_HTTP_TUNNELING 0x00000008 means client MUST use RPC over HTTP if configured.

[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] [EnableFlags (4 bytes)] Flag ENABLE_PERF_SENDGCDATA 0x00000010 means client MUST include performance data of the client that is communicating with the directory service.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] ExpiryTime [in block AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL is] 4 bytes.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] ExpiryTime (4 bytes): The number of milliseconds the client keeps unsent performance data before the data is expired.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] [ExpiryTime (4 bytes)] Expired data is not transmitted to the server.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONTROL Auxiliary Block Structure] [ExpiryTime (4 bytes)] This [Expiry Time] prevents the server from receiving stale performance information that is stored on the client.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_OSVERSIONINFO auxiliary block structure sends the server's operating system version information to the client.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] OSVersionInfoSize (4 bytes): The size of this AUX_OSVERSIONINFO structure.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] MajorVersion (4 bytes): The major version number of the operating system of the server.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] MinorVersion (4 bytes): The minor version number of the operating system of the server.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] BuildNumber (4 bytes): The build number of the operating system of the server.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved1 (132 bytes): Reserved.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [Reserved1] MUST be ignored when received.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ServicePackMajor (2 bytes): The major version number of the latest operating system service pack that is installed on the server.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ServicePackMinor (2 bytes): The minor version number of the latest operating system service pack that is installed on the server.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved2 (4 bytes): Reserved.
[In AUX_OSVERSIONINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [Reserved2] MUST be ignored when received.
[In AUX_EXORGINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_EXORGINFO auxiliary block structure informs the client of the presence of public folders within the organization.
[In AUX_EXORGINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] OrgFlags (4 bytes): The flags indicating the server organizational information.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R284.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_EXORGINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [OrgFlags (4 bytes)] The following table [table in section 2.2.2.19] specifies the valid values [PUBLIC_FOLDERS_ENABLED 0x00000001, USE_AUTODISCOVER_FOR_PUBLIC_FOLDER_CONFIGURATION 0x00000002].
[In AUX_EXORGINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [OrgFlags (4 bytes)] Flag PUBLIC_FOLDERS_ENABLED 0x00000001 means organization has public folders.

[In AUX_EXORGINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [OrgFlags (4 bytes)] Flag USE_AUTODISCOVER_FOR_PUBLIC_FOLDER_CONFIGURATION 0x00000002 means the client SHOULD<3> configure public folders using the Autodiscover Publishing and Lookup Protocol, as specified in [MS-OXDSCLI].
[In AUX_PERF_ACCOUNTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PERF_ACCOUNTINFO auxiliary block structure reports the client account information to the server.
[In AUX_PERF_ACCOUNTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ClientID (2 bytes): The client assigned identification number.
[In AUX_PERF_ACCOUNTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ClientID (2 bytes)] Maps to the ClientID of the AUX_PERF_CLIENTINFO structure, as specified in section 2.2.2.2.4.
[In AUX_PERF_ACCOUNTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_PERF_ACCOUNTINFO Auxiliary Block Structure] Account (16 bytes): A GUID representing the client account information that relates to the client identification number in the ClientID field.
[In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES auxiliary block structure informs the client that the server supports specific capabilities.
[In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerCapabilityFlags (4 bytes): A flag that indicates that the server supports specific capabilities.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requrements: MS-OXCRPC_R291004, MS-OXCRPC_R291007, MS-OXCRPC_R291009.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] The valid flag values are specified in the following table.
[In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] The value of Flag PACKED_FAST_TRANSFER_UPLOAD_BUFFERS is 0x00000001.

[In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] [PACKED_FAST_TRANSFER_UPLOAD_BUFFERS means]The server supports the client sending up packed upload extended buffers, see section 3.1.4.2.1.2.1, containing RopFastTransferDestinationPutBuffer ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.12.2).

[In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] [PACKED_FAST_TRANSFER_UPLOAD_BUFFERS means] The server supports the client sending up packed upload extended buffers, see section 3.1.4.2.1.2.1, containing RopFastTransferDestinationPutBuffetExtended ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.12.3).
[In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] The value of Flag PACKED_WRITE_STREAM_UPLOAD_BUFFERS is 0x00000002.

[In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] [PACKED_WRITE_STREAM_UPLOAD_BUFFERS means] The server supports the client sending up packed upload extended buffers, see section 3.1.4.2.1.2.1, containing RopWriteStreamExtended ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.4).
[In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] The value of Flag ULTRA_LARGE_PACKED_DOWNLOAD_BUFFERS is 0x00000008.
[In AUX_SERVER_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] [ULTRA_LARGE_PACKED_DOWNLOAD_BUFFERS means] The server supports the client asking for packed download chained buffers in EcDoRpcExt2.

[In AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES auxiliary block structure informs the client that the server supports multiple interfaces on a single HTTP endpoint.
[In AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] EndpointCapabilityFlag (4 bytes): A flag that indicates that the server combines capabilities on a single endpoint.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R1521.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] EndpointCapabilityFlag (4 bytes): The valid flag values [ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES_SINGLE_ENDPOINT 0x00000001] are specified in the following table.

[In AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] [EndpointCapabilityFlag (4 bytes)] The server supports combined Directory Service Referral interface (RFRI), name service provider interface (NSPI), and EMSMDB interface on a single HTTP endpoint.
[In AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] [EndpointCapabilityFlag (4 bytes)] For more information about RFRI, see [MS-OXABREF]. For more information about NSPI, see [MS-OXNSPI].

[In AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] [EndpointCapabilityFlag (4 bytes)] The server MAY<4> process requests for different interfaces independently even when requests are transmitted on the same connection.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R1921.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AUX_ENDPOINT_CAPABILITIES Auxiliary Block Structure] [EndpointCapabilityFlag (4 bytes)] A call to one interface is not to be blocked by a previous call to a different interface on the same connection.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO auxiliary block structure provides information about the client connection to be logged by the server.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ConnectionGUID (16 bytes): The GUID of the connection to the server.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] OffsetConnectionContextInfo (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the ConnectionContextInfo field.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [OffsetConnectionContextInfo (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the ConnectionContextInfo field is null or empty.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] Reserved (2 bytes): Padding to enforce alignment of the data on a 4-byte field.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ConnectionAttempts (2 bytes): The number of connection attempts.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ConnectionFlags (4 bytes): A flag designating the mode of operation.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ConnectionFlags (4 bytes): A value of 0x0001 for this field means that the client is running in cached mode.
[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ConnectionFlags (4 bytes)] A value of 0x0000 means that the client is not designating a mode of operation.

[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ConnectionContextInfo (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains opaque connection context information to be logged by the server.

[In AUX_CLIENT_CONNECTION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ConnectionContextInfo (variable)] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the OffsetConnectionContextInfo field value.
[In AUX_SERVER_SESSION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_SERVER_SESSION_INFO auxiliary block structure provides server information to be logged by the client.
[In AUX_SERVER_SESSION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] OffsetServerSessionContextInfo (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the ServerSessionContextInfo field.
[In AUX_SERVER_SESSION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [OffsetServerSessionContextInfo (2 bytes)] A value of zero indicates that the ServerSessionContextInfo field is null or empty.

[In AUX_SERVER_SESSION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] ServerSessionContextInfo (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains opaque server session context information to be logged by the client.

[In AUX_SERVER_SESSION_INFO Auxiliary Block Structure] [ServerSessionContextInfo (variable)] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the OffsetServerSessionContextInfo field value.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] The AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION auxiliary block structure identifies man-in-middle equipment used in messaging applications.

[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceManufacturerOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure, as specified in section 2.2.2.2, to the DeviceManufacturer field.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] A value of zero indicates that the DeviceManufacturer field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceModelOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the DeviceModel field.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] A value of zero indicates that the DeviceModel field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceSerialNumberOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the DeviceSerialNumber field.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] A value of zero indicates that the DeviceSerialNumber field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceVersionOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the DeviceVersion field.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] A value of zero indicates that the DeviceVersion field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceFirmwareVersionOffset (2 bytes): The offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure to the DeviceFirmwareVersion field.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] A value of zero indicates that the DeviceFirmwareVersion field is null or empty.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceManufacturer (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the name of the manufacturer of the device.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the value of the DeviceManufacturerOffset field.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceModel (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the model name of the device.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the value of the DeviceModelOffset field.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceSerialNumber (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the serial number of the device.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the value of the DeviceSerialNumberOffset field.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceVersion (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the version number of the device.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] This variable field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the value of the DeviceVersionOffset field.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] DeviceFirmwareVersion (variable): A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the firmware version of the device.
[In AUX_PROTOCOL_DEVICE_IDENTIFICATION Auxiliary Block Structure] This field is offset from the beginning of the AUX_HEADER structure by the value of the DeviceFirmwareVersionOffset field.
[In Protocol Details] The Wire Format Protocol contains two RPC interfaces: EMSMDB, as specified in section 3.1 and section 3.2, and AsyncEMSMDB as specified in section 3.3 and section 3.4.

[In Protocol Details] For some functionality through the EMSMDB interface, the client is required to first establish a session context handle by a successful call to the EcDoConnectEx method, as specified in section 3.1.4.1.
[In Protocol Details] The session context handle is an RPC context handle.
[In Protocol Details] All method calls that require a valid session context handle [EcDoDisconnect, EcRRegisterPushNotification, EcDoRpcExt2, EcDoAsyncConnectEx] are listed in the following table.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R372, MS-OXCRPC_R379.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Protocol Details] The interface of session context handle-based method EcDoDisconnect is EMSMDB.
[In Protocol Details] The interface of session context handle-based method EcRRegisterPushNotification is EMSMDB.
[In Protocol Details] The interface of session context handle-based method EcDoRpcExt2 is EMSMDB.
[In Protocol Details] The interface of session context handle-based method EcDoAsyncConnectEx is EMSMDB.
[In Protocol Details] For some functionality through the AsyncEMSMDB interface, the client is required to call specific interface methods first to establish an asynchronous context handle.
[In Protocol Details] The asynchronous context handle is an RPC context handle.
[In Protocol Details] To establish an asynchronous context handle, a call to the EcDoAsyncConnectEx method on the EMSMDB interface MUST be successful.
[In Protocol Details] All method calls that require a valid asynchronous context handle [EcDoAsyncWaitEx] are listed in the following table.
[In Protocol Details] The interface of EcDoAsyncWaitEx is AsyncEMSMDB.
[In EMSMDB Server Details] The server responds to messages it [the server] receives from the client.
[In Abstract Data Model] This section describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol [MS-OXCRPC].
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.

[In Abstract Data Model] This specification [MS-OXCRPC] does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model as long as their external behavior is consistent with that described in this specification.
[In Abstract Data Model] This protocol [MS-OXCRPC] includes the following abstract data model (ADM) element: Global.Handle, as specified in section 3.1.1.1.
[In Global] The following ADM element [Global.Handle] is maintained by the server for each session context.
[In Global.Handle] Global.Handle: Some methods on this interface [EMSMDB] require session context handle information to be stored on the server.
[In Global.Handle] Some methods on this interface [EMSMDB] require session context handle information to be used across multiple interface calls for a long duration of time.

[In Global.Handle] For these method [which requires session context handle information to be stored on the server and used across multiple interface calls for a long duration of time] calls, this protocol [MS-OXCRPC] is stateful.
[In Global.Handle] The server stores this session context information.
[In Global.Handle] The server provides a session context handle (the Global.Handle ADM element) to the client to make subsequent interface calls by using this same session context information.
[In Global.Handle] The server keeps a list of all active sessions and their associated session context information.
[In Global.Handle] Each session context is identified by a Global.Handle ADM element.
[In Global.Handle] After a session context has been established, a client can access messaging resources through this session context.
[In Global.Handle] The server keeps track of all open resources or any state information specific to the session on the session context.

[In Global.Handle] This [open resources or state information specific to the session on the Session Context] can include but is not limited to resources, such as folders, messages, tables, attachments, streams, associated asynchronous context handles, and notification callbacks.
[In Global.Handle] The server isolates all resources associated with one session context from all other session contexts on the server.
[In Global.Handle] Access to resources on one session context is not allowed using a session context handle of another session context.
[In Global.Handle] When the session context handle is destroyed, the session context and all session context information is destroyed.
[In Global.Handle] When the client connection is lost, the session context and all session context information are destroyed.
[In Global.Handle] When the client connection is lost, all open resources are closed.
[In Global.Handle] When the session context handle is destroyed, all open resources are closed.
[In Global.Handle] When the client connection is lost, all Server objects that are associated with the session context are released.
[In Global.Handle] When the session context is destroyed, all Server objects that are associated with the session context are released.

[In Initialization] The server initializes the RPC session by doing the following: 1. The server MUST register the different protocol sequences that will allow the server to communicate with the client.
[In Initialization] The supported protocol sequences are specified in section 2.1, including named endpoints.
[In Initialization] 2. The server MUST register the following authentication methods that are allowed on the EMSMDB interface.
[In Initialization] The server SHOULD<5> register the following authentication methods. [RPC_C_AUTHN_WINNT, RPC_C_AUTHN_GSS_KERBEROS, <6>RPC_C_AUTHN_GSS_NEGOTIATE, RPC_C_AUTHN_NONE].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1749, MS-OXCRPC_R1750, MS-OXCRPC_R1751, MS-OXCRPC_R1550, MS-OXCRPC_R1915.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Initialization] A client authenticates using one of the following authentication methods [RPC_C_AUTHN_WINNT, RPC_C_AUTHN_GSS_KERBEROS, <6>RPC_C_AUTHN_GSS_NEGOTIATE, RPC_C_AUTHN_NONE].
[In Initialization] 3. Start listening for RPCs.
[In Initialization] 4. Register the EMSMDB interface.
[In Initialization] 5. Register the EMSMDB interface to all the registered binding handles created previously.

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] This protocol [MS-OXCRPC] MUST indicate to the RPC runtime that it is to perform a strict Network Data Representation (NDR) data consistency check at target level 5.0, as specified in [MS-RPCE].

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] The methods [Opnum0NotUsedOnWire, EcDoDisconnect, Opnum2NotUsedOnWire, Opnum3NotUsedOnWire, EcRRegisterPushNotification, Opnum5NotUsedOnWire, EcDummyRpc, Opnum7NotUsedOnWire, Opnum8NotUsedOnWire, Opnum9NotUsedOnWire, EcDoConnectEx, EcDoRpcExt2, Opnum12NotUsedOnWire, Opnum13NotUsedOnWire, EcDoAsyncConnectEx] that this interface includes are listed in the following table [table in section 3.1.4].<7>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R1845.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] The phrase "Reserved" means that the client MUST NOT send the opnum.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] The server behavior is undefined.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum0NotUsedOnWire: Reserved.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum0NotUsedOnWire: opnum: 0
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method EcDoDisconnect: Closes a Session Context with the server.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R401.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method EcDoDisconnect: The Session Context is destroyed.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] [EcDoDisconnect] All associated server state, objects, and resources that are associated with the Session Context are released.

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] [EcDoDisconnect] The method requires an active session context handle to be returned from the EcDoConnectEx method, as specified in section 3.1.4.1.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum2NotUsedOnWire: Reserved.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum2NotUsedOnWire: opnum: 2
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum3NotUsedOnWire: Reserved.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum3NotUsedOnWire: opnum: 3
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method EcRRegisterPushNotification: Registers a callback address with the server for a Session Context.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R415.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] [EcRRegisterPushNotification] The callback address is used to notify the client of a pending event on the server.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R422.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] [EcRRegisterPushNotification] The method requires an active session context handle to be returned from the EcDoConnectEx method.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum5NotUsedOnWire: Reserved.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum5NotUsedOnWire: opnum: 5
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method EcDummyRpc: This call returns a SUCCESS.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R464.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] [EcDummyRpc] A client can use it to determine whether it can communicate with the server.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum7NotUsedOnWire: Reserved.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum7NotUsedOnWire: opnum: 7
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum8NotUsedOnWire: Reserved.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum8NotUsedOnWire: opnum: 8
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum9NotUsedOnWire: Reserved.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum9NotUsedOnWire: opnum: 9

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method EcDoConnectEx: Creates a session context handle on the server to be used in subsequent calls to EcDoDisconnect, EcDoRpcExt2, and EcDoAsyncConnectEx.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R475.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method EcDoRpcExt2: Passes generic ROP commands to the server for processing within a Session Context.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R1290.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] [EcDoRpcExt2] The method requires an active session context handle to be returned from the EcDoConnectEx method.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum12NotUsedOnWire: Reserved.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum12NotUsedOnWire: opnum: 12
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum13NotUsedOnWire: Reserved.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method Opnum13NotUsedOnWire: opnum: 13

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Method EcDoAsyncConnectEx: Binds a session context handle that is returned in the EcDoConnectEx method to a new asynchronous context handle that can be used in calls to the EcDoAsyncWaitEx method (section 3.3.4.1) in the AsyncEMSMDB interface.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R704.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] [EcDoAsyncConnectEx] The method requires an active session context handle to be returned from the EcDoConnectEx method.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] The EcDoConnectEx method establishes a new Session Context with the server.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] The Session Context is persisted on the server until the client disconnects by using the EcDoDisconnect method, as specified in section 3.1.4.3.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] This method [method EcDoConnectEx] returns a session context handle to be used by a client in subsequent calls.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] hBinding: A valid RPC binding handle.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] pcxh: A session context handle for the client.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] pcxh: On success, the server MUST return a unique value to be used as a session context handle.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R4790.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] pcxh: On success, the server MUST return a value to be used as a session context handle, and the value is not the same as the next EcDoConnectEx successful call.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcxh] On failure, the server MUST return a zero value as the session context handle.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] szUserDN: The DN of the user who is calling the EcDoConnectEx method in a directory service.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [szUserDN] The value of the szUserDN parameter is similar to the following: "/o=First Organization/ou=First Administrative Group/cn=recipients/cn=janedow".
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] ulFlags: A flag value that designates the type of connection being established.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] ulFlags: On input this parameter contains connection bits that MUST be set.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulFlags] All flag values not in the following table are reserved connection flags.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulFlags] [Value 0x00000000 means] requests connection without administrator privilege.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulFlags] [Value 0x00000001 means] Requests administrator behavior, which causes the server to check that the user has administrator privilege.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulFlags] [Value 0x00008000 means] If this flag is not passed and the client version (as specified by the rgwClientVersion parameter) is less than 12.00.0000.000 and no public folders are configured within the messaging system, the server MUST fail the connection attempt with error code ecClientVerDisallowed.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulFlags] The AUX_EXORGINFO auxiliary block structure, specified in section 2.2.2.2.17, informs the client of the presence of public folders within the organization.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulFlags] The use of the AUX_EXORGINFO auxiliary block structure is further defined in section 3.1.4.1.2.1.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulFlags] [Value 0x00008000 means] If this flag is passed and the client version (as specified by the rgwClientVersion parameter) is less than 12.00.0000.000, the server MUST NOT fail the connection attempt due to public folders not being configured within the messaging system.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulFlags] [Value 0x00008000 means] If the client version (as specified by the rgwClientVersion parameter) is greater than or equal to 12.00.0000.000, the server MUST NOT fail the connection attempt due to public folders not being configured within the messaging system (regardless of whether or not this flag is passed).
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] ulConMod: A client-derived 32-bit hash value of the DN passed in the szUserDN parameter.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulConMod] The server determines which public folder replica to use when accessing public folder information when more than one replica of a folder exists.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulConMod] The hash can be used to distribute client access across replicas in a deterministic way for load balancing.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] cbLimit: MUST be set to zero when sent and MUST be ignored when received.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] ulCpid: The code page in which text data is sent.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulCpid] If the Unicode format is not requested by the client on subsequent calls that use this Session Context, the ulCpid parameter sets the code page to be used in subsequent calls.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] ulLcidString: The local ID for everything other than sorting.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] ulLcidSort: The local ID for sorting.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] ulIcxrLink: A value used to link the Session Context created by this call with a currently existing Session Context on the server.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] To request Session Context linking, the client MUST pass the value of 0xFFFFFFFF.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] To link to an existing Session Context, this value [ulIcxrLink] is the session index value returned in the piCxr parameter from a previous call to the EcDoConnectEx method.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] In addition to passing the session index in the ulIcxrLink parameter, the client sets the pulTimeStamp parameter to the value that was returned in the pulTimeStamp parameter from the previous call to the EcDoConnectEx method.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] These two values [value returned in field piCxr from a previous EcDoConnectEx call and value returned in the pulTimeStamp field from the previous EcDoConnectEx call] MUST be used by the server to identify an active session with the same session index and session creation time stamp.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] If a session is found, the server MUST link the Session Context created by this call with the one found.<8>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1850, MS-OXCRPC_R508.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] [a server allows Session Context linking for the following reasons:] To consume a single Client Access License (CAL) for all the connections made from a single client computer.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] [a server allows Session Context linking for the following reasons:] This [a single Client Access License (CAL)] gives a client the ability to open multiple independent connections using more than one Session Context on the server but be seen to the server as only consuming a single CAL.<9>

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] [a server allows Session Context linking for the following reasons:] To get pending notification information for other sessions on the same client computer. For details, see [MS-OXCNOTIF].
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] Note that the ulIcxrLink parameter is defined as a 32-bit value.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] Other than passing 0xFFFFFFFF for no Session Context linking, the server only uses the low-order 16 bits as the session index.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [ulIcxrLink] This value [ulIcxrLink] is the value returned in the piCxr parameter from a previous call to the EcDoConnectEx method, which is the session index and defined as a 16-bit value.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] usFCanConvertCodePages: This parameter is reserved.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [usFCanConvertCodePages] The client MUST pass a value of 0x0001.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] pcmsPollsMax: An implementation-dependent value that specifies the number of milliseconds that a client waits between polling the server for event information.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcmsPollsMax] If the client does not support making asynchronous RPC calls for notifications as specified in section 3.3.4.1, the client can poll the server to determine whether any events are pending for the client.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcmsPollsMax] If the server does not support making asynchronous RPC calls for notifications as specified in section 3.3.4.1, the client can poll the server to determine whether any events are pending for the client.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] pcmsPollsMax: If the client is unable to receive notifications via UDP datagrams, as specified in [MS-OXCNOTIF] section 3.2.5.4 and [MS-OXCNOTIF] section 3.2.5.5.2, the client can poll the server to determine whether any events are pending for the client.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] pcRetry: An implementation-dependent value that specifies the number of times a client retries future RPCss using the session context handle returned in this call.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcRetry] This is for client RPCs that fail with RPC status code RPC_S_SERVER_TOO_BUSY (0x000006BB).
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcRetry] This is a suggested retry count for the client and is not to be enforced by the server.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcRetry] For more details about circumstances under which the RPC_S_SERVER_TOO_BUSY status code is returned, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.4.2.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcRetry] For more details about how the client handles the RPC_S_SERVER_TOO_BUSY status code, see section 3.2.4.4.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] pcmsRetryDelay: An implementation-dependent value that specifies the number of milliseconds a client waits before retrying a failed RPC.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcmsRetryDelay] If any future RPC to the server using the session context handle returned in this call fails with RPC status code RPC_S_SERVER_TOO_BUSY (0x000006BB), the client waits the number of milliseconds specified in this output parameter [pcmsRetryDelay] before retrying the call.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcmsRetryDelay] The number of times a client retries is returned in the pcRetry parameter.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcmsRetryDelay] This is a suggested delay for the client and is not to be enforced by the server.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] piCxr: A session index value that is associated with the session context handle returned from this call.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [piCxr] This value in conjunction with the session creation time stamp value returned in the pulTimeStamp parameter will be passed to a subsequent call to the EcDoConnectEx method, if the client requests to link two Session Contexts.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [piCxr] <10> The server MUST NOT assign the same session index value to two active Session Contexts.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R1943.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [piCxr] The server is free to return any 16-bit value for the session index.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [piCxr] The server MUST also use the session index when returning a RopPending ROP response ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.14.3) on calls to the EcDoRpcExt2 method, as specified in section 3.1.4.2, to tell the client which Session Context has pending notifications.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [piCxr] If Session Contexts are linked, a RopPending ROP response can be returned for any linked Session Context.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R1477.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [piCxr] If Session Contexts are linked, a RopPending can be returned for the linked Session Context.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] szDNPrefix: An implementation-dependent value that specifies a DN prefix that is used to build message recipients.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [szDNPrefix] An empty value indicates that there is nothing to prepend to recipient entries on messages.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] szDisplayName: The display name of the user associated with the szUserDN parameter.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] rgwClientVersion: The client protocol version that the server uses to determine what protocol functionality the client supports.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgwClientVersion] For more details about how version numbers are interpreted from the wire data, see section 3.2.4.1.3.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] rgwServerVersion: The server protocol version that the client uses to determine what protocol functionality the server supports.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgwServerVersion] For details about how version numbers are interpreted from the wire data, see section 3.1.4.1.3.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] rgwBestVersion: The minimum client protocol version that the server supports.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgwBestVersion] This information is useful if the call to the EcDoConnectEx method fails with return code ecVersionMismatch.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R549.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgwBestVersion] On success, the server returns the value passed in the rgwClientVersion parameter by the client.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgwBestVersion] The server cannot perform any client protocol version negotiation.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgwBestVersion] [If the client passes a client protocol version the server doesn't support,] The server can return the minimum client protocol version required to access the server and fail the call with ecVersionMismatch (0x80040110).

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgwBestVersion] [If the client passes a client protocol version the server supports,] The server can allow the client and return the value passed by the client in the rgwClientVersion parameter.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgwBestVersion] The server implementation sets the minimum client protocol version that is supported by the server.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgwBestVersion] For details about how version numbers are interpreted from the wire data, see section 3.1.4.1.3.1.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] pulTimeStamp: The creation time of the newly created Session Context.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pulTimeStamp] On input, a value used with the ulIcxrLink parameter to link the Session Context created by this call with an existing Session Context.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pulTimeStamp] If the ulIcxrLink parameter is not set to 0xFFFFFFFF, the client MUST pass in the value of the pulTimeStamp parameter returned from the server on a previous call to the EcDoConnectEx method.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pulTimeStamp] For more details, see the ulIcxrLink and piCxr parameter descriptions earlier in this section.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pulTimeStamp] If the server supports Session Context linking, the server verifies that there is a Session Context state with the unique identifier in the ulIcxrLink parameter and the Session Context state has a creation time stamp equal to the value passed in this parameter.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pulTimeStamp] If so [If the server supports Session Context linking, the server verifies that there is a Session Context state with the unique identifier ulIcxrLink and the server has a creation time stamp equal to the value passed in this parameter], the server MUST link the Session Context created by this [method EcDoConnectEx] call with the one found.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pulTimeStamp] If no such Session Context state is found, the server does not fail the EcDoConnectEx method call but simply does not link the Session Contexts.<11>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1944, MS-OXCRPC_R1435.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pulTimeStamp] On output, the server has to return a time stamp in which the new Session Context was created.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pulTimeStamp] The server saves the Session Context creation time stamp within the Session Context state for later use if a client attempts to link Session Contexts.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] rgbAuxIn: An auxiliary payload buffer prefixed by an RPC_HEADER_EXT structure, as specified in section 2.2.2.1.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgbAuxIn] Information stored in this structure determines how to interpret the data that follows the structure.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgbAuxIn] The length of the auxiliary payload buffer that includes the RPC_HEADER_EXT structure is contained in the cbAuxIn parameter.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgbAuxIn] For details about how to access the embedded auxiliary payload buffer, see section 3.1.4.1.1.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgbAuxIn] For details about how to interpret the auxiliary payload data, see section 3.1.4.1.2.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] cbAuxIn: The length of the rgbAuxIn parameter.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [cbAuxIn] If this value on input is larger than 0x00001008 bytes in size, the server SHOULD<12> fail with the RPC status code RPC_X_BAD_STUB_DATA (0x000006F7).
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R4875.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [cbAuxIn] If this value is greater than 0x00000000 and less than 0x00000008, the server SHOULD<13> <14> fail with ecRpcFailed (0x80040115).
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R1436, MS-OXCRPC_R1940.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [cbAuxIn] For more information on returning RPC status codes, see [C706].
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] rgbAuxOut: An auxiliary payload buffer prefixed by an RPC_HEADER_EXT structure (section 2.2.2.1).
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCRPC_R575.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] rgbAuxOut: On output, the server can return auxiliary payload data to the client in this parameter.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgbAuxOut] The server MUST include an RPC_HEADER_EXT structure before the auxiliary payload data.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgbAuxOut] For details about how to access the embedded auxiliary payload buffer, see section 3.1.4.1.1.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [rgbAuxOut] For details about how to interpret the auxiliary payload data, see section 3.1.4.1.2.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] pcbAuxOut: The length of the rgbAuxOut parameter.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcbAuxOut] If this value on input is larger than 0x00001008, the server MUST fail with the RPC status code RPC_X_BAD_STUB_DATA (0x000006F7).
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [pcbAuxOut] On output, this parameter contains the size of the data to be returned in the rgbAuxOut parameter.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] Return Values: If the method succeeds, the return value is 0.
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [Return Values] If the method fails, the return value is an implementation-specific error code.

[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [Return Values] If the method fails, the return value is one of the protocol-defined error codes [ecRpcAuthentication(0x000004B6), ecNotEncrypted(0x00000970), ecClientVerDisallowed(0x000004DF), ecLoginFailure(0x80040111), ecUnknownUser(0x000003EB), ecLoginPerm(0x000003F2), ecVersionMismatch(0x80040110), ecCachedModeRequired(0x000004E1), ecRpcHttpDisallowed(0x000004E0), ecProtocolDisabled(0x000007D8)] listed in the following table [table in section 3.1.4.11].
[In EcDoConnectEx Method (Opnum 10)] [Error Codes] [ecAccessDenied (0x80070005) means] The szUserDN parameter is empty.<15>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCRPC_R4887, MS-OXCRPC_R1437.
